posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked:
When we use SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle our robot drives on a approximately 10 degree angle from straight.    Additionally when setting and angle they are all out by the same ~10 degrees

When using SwerveRequest.FieldCentric it works normally.

Can anyone suggest what might be wrong?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Did you try adjusting the PID ?

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked: I haven’t tried this yet, but it’s my understanding that the PID is used to maintain rotation and not translation.

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked:
I drew a MS paint drawing to better explain the problem. image 842×576 7.29 KB

image 842×576 7.29 KB

image 842×576 7.29 KB

posts.name: Trevor G.
posts.cooked:
This is bit of a reach, but are you setting the .withVelocityX() and .withVelocityY() with the same parameters as your SwerveRequest.FieldCentric() ?  When we started experimenting with FieldCentricFacingAngle , we accidentally swapped them like this:

In simulation, our robot could only ever slide at an angle, but I don’t remember if it was 10 degrees.

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked: We have that correct, but I appreciate the idea.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: That is strange, the translation portion of the code is identical for FieldCentric and FieldCentricFacingAngle . Is the robot holding an angle while driving forward when you get this behavior, or is it rotating? If it’s rotating, do you see similar behavior with FieldCentric while rotating? Maybe you need to adjust kCoupleRatio .

posts.name: Adam Bochek
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

Is the robot holding an angle while driving forward when you get this behavior

Yes it holds and angle correctly.

It drives as if the whole world was rotated 10 degrees,  if we snap to 0 degrees it point at approximately 10 degrees.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Bochek:

if we snap to 0 degrees it point at approximately 10 degrees

This part confuses me, are you talking translation or rotation? I would try putting the pose on your dashboard and see what the robot thinks the rotation is, and if it’s drifting.
